author: AETerry
title: Stocking Stuffer Angel
review:
Ah yes, one of many sets gotten in various years as a Stocking Stuffer on Christmas Morning.

 

I liked this best as it wasn't a Santa Claus model, nothing against the big guy in red, but I'd had 2 others and didn't want to redundency.

 

There's a decent amount of pieces to work with, put the main model together and display it for a Christmas Decoration.

author: J14T14
title: Heavenly LEGO Set
review: I got this LEGO set second hand from my Great Aunt. It used to belong to her kids, but they didn't want them anymore since they were adults. Anyway, this is a nice little set for its time. The shaping of the hands and the feet, the garment, and the wings are pretty good. This set has fallen off of my shelf a couple of times and it has survived the fall without breaking. Only the halo has fallen off. The 2x2 round yellow plate is held onto the head by two 1x1 round clear plates. This is not the best connection, but it does the job well. Overall, this is a great little set. LEGO probably will never do something like this again due to the religious reference, so it makes this set all the more special.

author: HomeOnTheRange
title: Cute angel
review:
I pulled this out of the box of Legos from our childhood and thought it was very cute.  The halo is nicely done with two colourless, clear single circles in the back of the head to elevate the yellow disc above it.  The cool part about this set is that if you have a lot of other Legos, you could build it without shelling out money for the set.  It takes very little time or skill to build.  The instructions are available on the web.  Here is one location: https://lego.brickinstructions.com/en/lego_instructions/set/1626/Angel

I put the angel on top of the Emergency Treatment Center (6380).  It doesn't have to be just for Christmas!  Alternatively, if you have extra bricks, you could use the instructions to make a whole host of angels for a Christmas display.
